Introduction

The visual pathway is the neural system responsible for transmitting visual information from the retina to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe.  It is essential for the perception of form, color, motion, and spatial orientation.  Visual processing begins with optical refraction by the cornea and lens, followed by the conversion of light into electrical signals by the retinal photoreceptors.  These signals are then relayed through a series of precisely organized neural structures, including the optic nerves, optic chiasm, optic tracts, lateral geniculate nuclei, optic radiations, and, finally, the visual cortex.

The eye

Refraction of light



Refraction is the bending of light as it passes through media of different optical densities.  It is essential for vision because it allows incoming light rays, which enter the eye from various angles, to be focused precisely onto the retina.  A sharp image is formed only when light converges accurately on the retinal photoreceptors, particularly in the fovea centralis.  Without proper refraction, light scatters and is improperly focused, resulting in a blurred image.



The eye has several structures that bend and focus light onto the retina (

figure 1
):



  • Cornea:  The eye's first and most powerful refractive surface, the cornea is the transparent, dome-shaped outer layer of the eye, which has a fixed curvature and contributes approximately 70% of the eye's total refractive power.
  • Aqueous humor:  This clear fluid within the anterior chamber contributes minimally to refraction but helps transmit light between the cornea and lens.
  • Lens:  The second major refractive structure of the eye, the lens has an adjustable curvature that allows for accommodation, the process by which the lens changes its shape to focus on objects at varying distances.
    • Near vision:  Ciliary muscle contracts → zonular fibers relax → lens thickens and becomes more convex → increases refractive power for focusing on near objects.
    • Distance vision:  Ciliary muscle relaxes → zonular fibers tighten → lens flattens → decreases refractive power for distant objects.


After light passes through the lens and vitreous compartment, the image created on the retina is inverted and reversed (

figure 2
).  This means that the temporal (lateral) retinas process images from the nasal (medial) visual field, and the nasal retinas process images from the temporal visual field.

Refractive errors



Visual impairments due to refractive errors include:



  • Myopia (nearsightedness) (
    figure 3
    ):  Light focuses in front of the retina, causing poor distance vision.
  • Hyperopia (farsightedness) (
    figure 4
    ):  Light focuses behind the retina, causing poor near vision.
  • Astigmatism (
    figure 5
    ):  Irregular curvature of the cornea or lens leads to a distorted, blurred image.
  • Presbyopia:  Age-related loss of lens elasticity results in impaired accommodation, especially for near focus (eg, reading).

The retina

The neural sensor



Located at the back of the eye, the retina converts light into electrical signals that are then sent to the brain via the optic nerve.  It contains layers of specialized cells that sequentially process visual information (

figure 6
).



  • Photoreceptors:  Located in the outermost layer of the retina, photoreceptors hyperpolarize in response to light and modulate downstream neurons.

    • Rods:  Highly sensitive to light; provide night vision and low-resolution, monochromatic (no color) vision.  Rods are concentrated in the peripheral retina.
    • Cones:  Enable daytime and color vision (red, green, blue); responsible for high visual acuity.  Cones are concentrated in the fovea centralis.
  • Bipolar cells:  Transmit signals from photoreceptors to ganglion cells.
  • Ganglion cells:  Receive input from bipolar cells and generate action potentials.  Axons of ganglion cells form the optic nerve.
  • Horizontal and amacrine cells:  Modulate and integrate signals to enhance contrast, motion detection, and spatial resolution.

Special regions of the retina



  • Macula lutea:  The central area of the retina with a high density of cones; specialized for high-acuity central vision.
  • Fovea centralis:  The center of the macula; a cone-only region with the sharpest visual resolution.
  • Optic disc:  Site where ganglion cell axons converge to form the optic nerve; no rods or cones are present, resulting in a physiologic "blind spot" (
    figure 7
    ).

Retinal pathology



  • Central retinal artery occlusion:  Reduction or complete cessation of retinal perfusion leads to retinal ischemia and the sudden onset of painless monocular vision loss.
  • Age-related macular degeneration:  Progressive loss of central vision impairs reading and facial recognition; peripheral vision is preserved.
  • Retinal detachment:  Separation of the neurosensory retina (eg, photoreceptors) from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (which provides oxygen and nutrients) impairs the function of retinal cells, often presenting with flashes of light and floaters.  It can lead to permanent photoreceptor degeneration and vision loss if not corrected.

Neural visual pathway



Neural signals travel along the following visual pathway:  Retina → optic nerve → optic chiasm → optic tracts → lateral geniculate nucleus → optic radiations → primary visual cortex (

figure 8
).  Lesions along this pathway produce various types of visual deficits based on the location and the nerve fibers that are affected.

Optic nerve (CN II)



  • Formed by retinal ganglion cell axons.  Lesions in the optic nerve (eg, central retinal artery occlusion, optic neuritis) cause monocular blindness (anopia) (
    figure 9
    ).

Optic chiasm



  • Fibers from the nasal half of the retina (which process the temporal visual field) cross at the optic chiasm, but the temporal retinal fibers (which process the nasal visual fields) remain ipsilateral.  The hemivisual fields of each eye are processed on the contralateral side of the brain (eg, left visual field of the left and right eye is processed in the right hemisphere) (
    figure 10
    ).
  • Lesions at the optic chiasm (eg, compression by a pituitary adenoma (
    figure 11
    )) cause a bitemporal hemianopia (
    figure 12
    ).

Optic tracts



  • The optic tracts carry contralateral visual field information from the optic chiasm to the lateral geniculate nucleus.
  • Lesions in the optic tract (eg, occlusion of the anterior choroidal artery) cause a contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of the same visual field in both eyes) (
    figure 13
    ).

Lateral geniculate nucleus



  • The lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) is a 6-layered visual relay center within the posterolateral thalamus that sends fibers to the visual cortex via optic radiations.
  • Lesions in this region (eg, stroke or tumor involving the LGN) cause a contralateral homonymous visual field deficit.

Optic radiations



  • Inferior optic radiations:  Carry information from the superior visual field (inferior retina) through the temporal lobe (Meyer loop) to the visual cortex.  Lesions in this region (eg, stroke or mass involving the temporal lobe) cause a contralateral homonymous superior quadrantanopia ("pie in the sky") (
    figure 14
    ).
  • Superior optic radiations:  Carry information from the inferior visual field (superior retina) through the parietal lobe to the visual cortex.  Lesions in this region (eg, stroke or mass involving the parietal lobe) cause a contralateral homonymous inferior quadrantanopia ("pie on the floor") (
    figure 15
    ).


Large infarctions involving the territory supplied by the middle cerebral artery can damage both the upper and lower limbs of the optic radiations, resulting in homonymous hemianopia.

Primary visual cortex



  • Located in the occipital lobe and is retinotopically organized (eg, specific retinal areas map to specific areas of the visual cortex).
    • Macular vision is processed by the posterior cortex.
    • Peripheral vision is processed by the anterior cortex.
  • Lesions in this region (eg, occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery) cause a contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (the cortical structures responsible for macular vision are dual-supplied from the middle and posterior cerebral arteries).


After visual information is received in the occipital cortex, it is relayed along distinct pathways to association cortices for higher-order processing (

figure 16
).  The ventral (P) pathways project to the occipitotemporal association cortex for the identification of letters, colors, shapes, and faces (ie, what is it?).  The dorsal (M) pathways project to the parietooccipital association cortex for processing of motion and spatial relationships (ie, where is it?).

Summary



Vision begins when light is refracted by the cornea and lens and focused onto the retina, where rods and cones convert light into neural signals.  These signals travel via ganglion cells into the optic nerve, cross partially at the optic chiasm, and continue through the optic tracts, lateral geniculate nucleus, and optic radiations to reach the primary visual cortex.  Lesions along this pathway produce characteristic visual field defects (

figure 17
).
